vulnerabilities.message: Never create NULL ACLs; an attacker can set it to Everyone (Deny All Access), which would even forbid administrator access (CWE-732).
Never create NULL ACLs; an attacker can set it to Everyone (Deny All Access), which would even forbid administrator access (CWE-732).
Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use fgets() instead.

vulnerabilities.message: Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned] (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Consider strcat_s, strlcat, snprintf, or automatically resizing strings.

vulnerabilities.message: Requires maximum length in CHARACTERS, not bytes (CWE-120).
Easily used incorrectly (e.g., incorrectly computing the correct maximum size to add) [MS-banned] (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Consider strcat_s, strlcat, or automatically resizing strings.

vulnerabilities.message: Requires maximum length in CHARACTERS, not bytes (CWE-120).
Potential format string problem (CWE-134).
vulnerabilities.solution: Make format string constant.

vulnerabilities.message: If syslog's format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use a constant format string for syslog.

vulnerabilities.message: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20).
vulnerabilities.solution: Specify a limit to %s, or use a different input function.

vulnerabilities.message: The scanf() family's %s operation, without a limit specification, permits buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20).
vulnerabilities.solution: Specify a limit to %s, or use a different input function.

vulnerabilities.message: If format strings can be influenced by an attacker, they can be exploited (CWE-134).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use a constant for the format specification.

vulnerabilities.message: Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use sprintf_s, snprintf, or vsnprintf.

vulnerabilities.message: Does not check for buffer overflows when concatenating to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120).
Does not check for buffer overflows (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use sprintf_s, snprintf, or vsnprintf.

vulnerabilities.message: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Consider using snprintf, strcpy_s, or strlcpy (warning: strncpy easily misused).

vulnerabilities.message: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination [MS-banned] (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Consider using a function version that stops copying at the end of the buffer.

vulnerabilities.message: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely (CWE-78).
vulnerabilities.solution: Specify the application path in the first argument, NOT as part of the second, or embedded spaces could allow an attacker to force a different program to run.

vulnerabilities.message: This causes a new process to execute and is difficult to use safely (CWE-78).
vulnerabilities.solution: Specify the application path in the first argument, NOT as part of the second, or embedded spaces could allow an attacker to force a different program to run.

vulnerabilities.message: Ensure that the full path to the library is specified, or current directory may be used (CWE-829, CWE-20).
vulnerabilities.solution: Use a flag like LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_SYSTEM32 or LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_APPLICATION_DIR to search only desired folders.

vulnerabilities.message: Some older implementations do not protect against internal buffer overflows (CWE-120, CWE-20).
vulnerabilities.solution: Check implementation on installation, or limit the size of all string inputs.

vulnerabilities.message: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues (CWE-119!/CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Perform bounds checking, use functions that limit length, or ensure that the size is larger than the maximum possible length.

vulnerabilities.message: Check when opening files - can an attacker redirect it (via symlinks), force the opening of special file type (e.g., device files), move things around to create a race condition, control its ancestors, or change its contents? (CWE-362).
Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Make sure destination can always hold the source data.

vulnerabilities.message: Statically-sized arrays can be improperly restricted, leading to potential overflows or other issues (CWE-119!/CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Perform bounds checking, use functions that limit length, or ensure that the size is larger than the maximum possible length.

vulnerabilities.message: Does not check for buffer overflows when copying to destination (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Make sure destination can always hold the source data.

vulnerabilities.message: Requires maximum length in CHARACTERS, not bytes (CWE-120).
Does not handle strings that are not \0-terminated; if given one it may perform an over-read (it could cause a crash if unprotected) (CWE-126).
It's unclear if the %s limit in the format string is small enough (CWE-120).
vulnerabilities.solution: Check that the limit is sufficiently small, or use a different input function.
